sect1.title: Procedures for Gathering Information
sect1.para: The foundation of a good therapeutic alliance is a collaborative relationship where an affective bond between the clinician and the client develops and facilitates the process of agreeing on and progressing with selected treatment goals (Lilienfeld et al., 2012 ). To elicit good information, it is worthwhile taking the time to create a sense of safety so that the client feels comfortable sharing private details about their thoughts, feelings, and behaviors. To establish a therapeutic alliance, it is critical to express compassion, show a genuine interest in the client’s concerns, and engage the client as a collaborator in treatment. Client collaboration can be obtained through mutually setting goals for treatment and sharing impressions of the treatment and progress. Reviewing assessment assessment results with the client and providing psychoeducation have the potential to enhance the therapeutic alliance as it can assuage the client’s concerns about the source of their distress and their ability to cope and change. It is incumbent to continue gathering relevant information and monitoring progress at each stage of therapy.10.2 2014Table 10.2
Evaluative questions in the diagnostic process of trauma and stressor related disorders

entry.para: PTSD/Acute Stress Disorder
PTSD/Acute Stress Disorder (continued)
Adjustment disorder
Prolonged grief disorder
Trauma exposure:
What was the stressful experience?
Could you share what happened?

If client is uncomfortable sharing about the trauma, say: I realize talking about the event may be hard. Given my questions today are for diagnostic purposes it may be helpful to share briefly and not go into details
If client describes indirect exposure, ask:
In what capacity were you exposed? How often were you exposed? Describe the situations you were exposed to
Intrusive symptoms:
Are you experiencing any unwanted memories related to the stressful experience?
How about dreams or nightmares related to the stressful experience?
Could you share what they look like? How frequent are these nightmares/memories?
What do you do when you these memories resurface?
Do you experience times when you feel like you are reliving the stressful event and not aware of what goes on around you? Could you describe? How frequent are these flashbacks?
Avoidance symptoms:
How are you coping with the distress you feel about the stressful experience?
Do you find yourself trying to avoid thoughts or feelings that you connect with the stressful experience?
Do you try to avoid people or other external reminders like places or situations that you connect with the stressful experience?
Negative changes in mood and cognition:
Have you noticed changes in mood after the stressful experience? Could you describe what feelings you started experiencing more?
Have you noticed changes in how you perceive yourself, other people, or the world after the stressful experience?
How have key relationships in your life been impacted by the stressful experience?
Can you recall key details or the stressful experience?
Hyperarousal symptoms:
Since the stressful event occurred—
What has your sleep been like?
Do you experience anger outbursts? Could you describe one?
Do you have muscle tension? Feeling keyed up?
Changes in concentration (e. g. reading a book/article)?
Duration:
How long have you been having these experiences—More than a month or less than a month?
Impact on quality of life:
What key areas in your life—Family, friends, work, activities—Have been negatively impacted as a result of the stressful experience?
From 0 (not at all) to 10 (worst experience) how badly have these areas been impacted? Could you give an example?
Rule-outs:
Just before you started having these experiences (e. g. intrusive thoughts, avoidance, etc.)—Were you engaging in alcohol or substance use? Were you medically ill?
Delayed onset:
If multiple months/years passed since the stressful experience, ask: When did you start having these experiences? How long after the stressful experience?
Stressor:
What was the stressor? Could you share what happened?

If client is uncomfortable sharing about the stressor, say: I realize talking about the event may be hard. Given my questions today are for diagnostic purposes, it may be helpful to share briefly and not go into details
Marked disproportionate distress:
Could you describe the distress you experience as a result of the stressor? How is the distress reflected in your daily life?
What emotions are you experiencing?
From 0 (lowest) to 10 (highest) what is the intensity of the emotional experience?
What are some key changes in your behavior that you experience because of the stressor?
How is your behavior different than the one before the stressor took place?
What key areas in your life—Family, friends, work, activities—Have been negatively impacted following the stressor?
Onset and duration:
How long after the stressor began did you start having the emotional and behavioral experiences you described?
How long after the stressor ended did you continue having these experiences?
How long have you been having these experiences overall?
Trauma/stressor:
Could you share who passed away and circumstances surrounding the passing? What was your relationship with the deceased?
If client is uncomfortable sharing, say: I realize talking about the event may be hard. Given my questions today are for diagnostic purposes it may be helpful to share briefly and not go into details
Separation distress:
Do you find yourself longing for the deceased? Could you describe what your yearning looks like?
Do you experience memories of the deceased? What does it look like?
Cognitive, behavioral, and emotional symptoms:
Do you feel like a different person since the deceased’s passing? If so, how?
How hard has it been coming to terms with the deceased’s passing?
Do you try to avoid reminders of the death? What type of reminders and how do you avoid?
Could you describe your emotional experiences since the death?
How have your life’s routines in key areas (e. g. family, friends, work) change following the death?
Is it hard for you to experience either positive or negative emotions?
Is it difficult for you to connect to other people since the death?
Duration and impact:
When did the passing take place?
How frequent have these experiences been?
Have they been interfering with your ability to take care of important things in your life?
What does bereavement look like in the culture you subscribe to?

sect1.para: When appropriate, it is also beneficial to obtain information from collateral sources such as family members, spouses, partners, or close friends, as they can shed light on the client’s behavior and current concerns. However, any interviews with a third party should be done with the client’s informed consent. Because of the clinician’s primary legal and ethical responsibility to maintain the client’s confidentiality, obtaining a client’s verbal consent and securing a client-signed Release of Information (ROI) form is advisable.
